poem:
**The Irony of Return**

A craftsman knows the feel of missing,  
his hands once mended phantom limbs.  
Now he rides a gurney to where he healed.  
The world tips its cruel hat to fate,  
as he lies learning absence, anew—  
a sock with no filled foot,  
an empty sleeve pinned to history's thread.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "He worked with artificial limbs for decades. Then a lorry ripped off his right arm. What happened when the expert became the patient? When the air ambulance brought Jim Ashworth-Beaumont to King’s College hospital in south-east London, nobody thought he had a hope. He had been cycling home when a lorry driver failed to spot him alongside his trailer while turning left after a set of traffic lights. The vehicle’s wheels opened his torso like". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
